questions.question: The body fluid that constitutes the internal environment of the body is called:
questions.explanation: Blood, lymph, and interstitial fluid together constitute the body fluids which form the internal environment of the body. (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: Blood is a special connective tissue consisting of:
options: Cells and fluid matrix called plasma
questions.explanation: Blood is a special connective tissue consisting of a fluid matrix, plasma, and formed elements. (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: Plasma constitutes approximately what percentage of blood?
questions.explanation: Plasma constitutes about 55 per cent of the blood. (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: Water forms about what percentage of plasma?
questions.explanation: 90-92 per cent of plasma is water and proteins contribute 6-8 per cent of it. (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a plasma protein?
questions.explanation: Fibrinogens, globulins and albumins are the major plasma proteins. Haemoglobin is present in RBCs, not in plasma. (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: Fibrinogen is needed for:
questions.explanation: Fibrinogens are needed for clotting or coagulation of blood. (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: Globulins are primarily involved in:
questions.explanation: Globulins primarily are involved in defence mechanisms of the body (immunity). (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: Albumins help in:
questions.explanation: Albumins help in osmotic balance of the blood. (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: Plasma without clotting factors is called:
questions.explanation: Plasma without the clotting factors is called serum. (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: The formed elements of blood are:
questions.explanation: Erythrocytes, leucocytes, and platelets are collectively called formed elements and they constitute nearly 45 per cent of the blood. (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: Erythrocytes (RBCs) are formed in:
questions.explanation: Erythrocytes or red blood cells (RBC) are the most abundant of all the cells in blood. RBCs are formed in the red bone marrow in the adults. (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: Mature mammalian RBCs are:
questions.explanation: A healthy individual has 12-16 gms of haemoglobin in every 100 ml of blood. These molecules are called RBC and they lack nucleus (enucleated) in mammals and are biconcave in shape. (NCERT Page 230)

questions.question: The normal RBC count in adult males is:
questions.explanation: RBC count in adult males is about 5 millions to 5.5 millions per mm³ of blood. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: RBCs have an average life span of:
questions.explanation: RBCs have an average life span of 120 days after which they are destroyed in the spleen (graveyard of RBCs). (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: The 'graveyard of RBCs' is:
questions.explanation: RBCs have an average life span of 120 days after which they are destroyed in the spleen (graveyard of RBCs). (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Leucocytes (WBCs) are also known as:
questions.explanation: Leucocytes are also known as white blood cells (WBC) as they are colourless due to the lack of haemoglobin. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Leucocytes are generally:
questions.explanation: They are nucleated and are relatively short lived. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Leucocytes are of two main types:
questions.explanation: We have two main categories of WBCs – granulocytes and agranulocytes. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils are examples of:
questions.explanation: Neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils are different types of granulocytes. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Lymphocytes and monocytes are examples of:
questions.explanation: Lymphocytes and monocytes are different types of agranulocytes. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: The most abundant WBCs are:
questions.explanation: Neutrophils are the most abundant cells (60-65 per cent) of the total WBCs and basophils are the least (0.5-1 per cent). (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: The percentage of neutrophils in total WBC count is:
questions.explanation: Neutrophils are the most abundant cells (60-65 per cent) of the total WBCs. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: The least abundant WBCs are:
questions.explanation: Basophils are the least (0.5-1 per cent) among all WBCs. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Platelets are also called:
questions.explanation: Platelets also called thrombocytes, are cell fragments produced from megakaryocytes. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Platelets are produced from:
questions.explanation: Platelets are cell fragments produced from megakaryocytes (special cells in the bone marrow). (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: The normal count of platelets is:
questions.explanation: Blood normally contains 150,000-350,000 platelets/mm³. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Platelets are essential for:
questions.explanation: Platelets can release a variety of substances most of which are involved in the coagulation or clotting of blood. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: The ABO blood grouping is based on the presence or absence of:
questions.explanation: ABO grouping is based on the presence or absence of two surface antigens (chemicals that can induce immune response) on the RBCs namely A and B. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Blood group A has:
questions.explanation: Blood group A has antigen A on RBCs and antibody b (anti-B) in plasma. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: The universal donor blood group is:
questions.explanation: Persons with blood group O can donate blood to persons with any other blood group and hence are called 'universal donors'. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: The universal recipient blood group is:
questions.explanation: Persons with blood group AB can accept blood from persons with AB as well as the other groups of blood and hence are called 'universal recipients'. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Blood group O has:
options: No antigens, both antibodies (a and b)
questions.explanation: Blood group O has no antigens on RBCs but has both antibodies a (anti-A) and b (anti-B) in plasma. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Blood group AB has:
questions.explanation: Blood group AB has both antigens A and B on RBCs but no antibodies in plasma. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: Another blood grouping based on presence or absence of a protein antigen on RBCs is:
questions.explanation: Another blood grouping is also done based on the presence or absence of another antigen called Rh antigen (Rh factor) on the surface of RBCs. (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: The Rh factor was first discovered in:
questions.explanation: Rh antigen similar to one present in Rhesus monkeys (hence Rh). (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: A person with Rh+ blood:
options: Has both Rh antigen and antibodies
questions.explanation: Majority (nearly 80 per cent) of humans possess Rh antigens on their RBCs and are called Rh positive (Rh+ve). Those who do not have Rh antigens are Rh negative (Rh-ve). (NCERT Page 231)

questions.question: If an Rh-ve person receives Rh+ve blood for the first time:
questions.explanation: A special case of Rh incompatibility (fetomaternal) has been observed between the Rh-ve blood of a pregnant mother with Rh+ve blood of the foetus. Rh antigens of the foetus do not get exposed to the Rh-ve blood of the mother in the first pregnancy as the two bloods are well separated by the placenta. However, during the delivery of the first child, there is a possibility of exposure of the maternal blood to small amounts of the Rh+ve blood from the foetus. In such cases, the mother starts preparing antibodies against Rh in her blood. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: Erythroblastosis foetalis occurs when:
options: Rh-ve mother carries Rh+ve foetus (second pregnancy)
questions.explanation: During subsequent pregnancies, the Rh antibodies from the mother (Rh-ve) can leak into the blood of the foetus (Rh+ve) and destroy the foetal RBCs. This could be fatal to the foetus or could cause severe anaemia and jaundice to the baby. This condition is called erythroblastosis foetalis. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: Coagulation of blood involves the conversion of:
questions.explanation: The mechanism of clotting involves a cascade of events. An enzyme complex, thrombokinase is formed by a series of linked enzymatic reactions (cascade process) involving a number of factors present in the plasma in an inactive state. Thrombokinase converts prothrombin to thrombin. Thrombin converts fibrinogen to fibrin. The fibrin threads form the basis of a blood clot. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: Prothrombin is converted to thrombin by:
questions.explanation: Thrombokinase converts prothrombin to thrombin in the presence of Ca²⁺. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: Calcium ions are required for:
questions.explanation: Calcium ions play a very important role in clotting. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: Lymph is a fluid that:
questions.explanation: As the blood passes through the capillaries in tissues, some water along with many small water-soluble substances move out into the intercellular spaces forming the interstitial fluid. This fluid is called lymph and it is colourless. It contains WBCs and clotting factors. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: Lymph differs from blood in that it:
questions.explanation: Lymph is similar to blood plasma but has lesser proteins. It is devoid of RBCs but has leucocytes. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: The lymphatic system consists of:
options: Lymph, lymph vessels, and lymph nodes
questions.explanation: Lymph, lymphatic capillaries, lymphatic vessels, lymph nodes, and lymphoid organs together constitute the lymphatic system. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: An important function of lymph is:
options: Transport of digested fats from intestine
questions.explanation: The lymphatic system is an important component of the circulatory system. It helps in the transport of fats. Lymph nodes are secondary lymphoid organs important for immunity. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: The human heart is enclosed in a double-walled membranous bag called:
questions.explanation: The human heart is situated in the thoracic cavity, in between the two lungs, slightly tilted to the left. It has the size of a clenched fist. It is protected by a double-walled membranous bag, pericardium. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: The fluid in the pericardial space is called:
questions.explanation: The pericardial space is filled with pericardial fluid which reduces friction and protects the heart. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: The human heart has:
questions.explanation: The human heart has four chambers, two relatively small upper chambers called atria and two larger lower chambers called ventricles. (NCERT Page 232)

questions.question: The wall of the ventricles is thicker than the atria because:
options: Ventricles pump blood out of the heart
questions.explanation: A muscular wall, the inter-ventricular septum, separates the left and the right ventricles. The ventricles have thicker walls than the atria because they pump blood to longer distances. (NCERT Page 233)

questions.question: The opening between the right atrium and right ventricle is guarded by:
questions.explanation: The opening between the right atrium and the right ventricle is guarded by a valve formed of three muscular flaps called tricuspid valve. (NCERT Page 233)

questions.question: The bicuspid valve (mitral valve) is present between:
questions.explanation: The opening between the left atrium and left ventricle is guarded by a bicuspid (mitral) valve. (NCERT Page 233)

questions.question: The openings of the right and left ventricles into the pulmonary artery and aorta respectively are guarded by:
questions.explanation: The openings of the right and the left ventricles into the pulmonary artery and aorta respectively are provided with the semilunar valves. (NCERT Page 233)

questions.question: The valves in the heart allow the flow of blood:
questions.explanation: The valves in the heart allow the flow of blood only in one direction - from atria to ventricles and from ventricles to pulmonary artery/aorta. (NCERT Page 233)

questions.question: The nodal tissue in the heart is composed of:
questions.explanation: The nodal tissue is a specialised cardiac musculature located in the heart. A patch of this tissue is present in the right upper corner of the right atrium called the sino-atrial node (SAN). (NCERT Page 233)

questions.question: The SA node is located in:
options: Right upper corner of right atrium
questions.explanation: A patch of this tissue is present in the right upper corner of the right atrium called the sino-atrial node (SAN). (NCERT Page 233)

questions.question: The pacemaker of the heart is:
questions.explanation: Since it initiates and maintains the rhythmic contractile activity of the heart, it is responsible for generating the cardiac impulse. It is known as the pacemaker of the heart. (NCERT Page 233)

questions.question: The AV node is located in:
options: Lower left corner of right atrium, close to AV septum
questions.explanation: Another mass of this tissue is seen in the lower left corner of the right atrium close to the atrio-ventricular septum called the atrio-ventricular node (AVN). (NCERT Page 233)

questions.question: The bundle of His passes through:
questions.explanation: A bundle of nodal fibres, atrioventricular bundle (AV bundle), also called bundle of His continues from the AVN which passes through the atrio-ventricular septa to emerge on the top of the inter-ventricular septum and immediately divides into a right and left bundle. (NCERT Page 233)

questions.question: Purkinje fibres are found in:
questions.explanation: These branches give rise to minute fibres throughout the ventricular musculature of the respective sides and are called Purkinje fibres. (NCERT Page 233)

questions.question: The correct sequence of cardiac conduction system is:
options: Bundle of His → SA node → AV node → Purkinje fibres
Purkinje fibres → AV node → SA node → Bundle of His
SA node → AV node → Bundle of His → Purkinje fibres
AV node → SA node → Bundle of His → Purkinje fibres
questions.explanation: The cardiac impulse is initiated by the SA node and spreads through the atria to the AV node, then through the bundle of His and Purkinje fibres to the ventricles. (NCERT Page 233-234)

questions.question: The cardiac cycle is the sequence of events during:
questions.explanation: The sequential events in the heart which are repeated in the same order are called the cardiac cycle. To begin with, all the four chambers of heart are in a relaxed state (joint diastole). (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: The duration of a cardiac cycle is approximately:
questions.explanation: A cardiac cycle takes about 0.8 seconds to complete. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: The contraction phase of the heart is called:
questions.explanation: Systole is the contraction phase of the heart chambers. Atrial systole pushes blood into ventricles, and ventricular systole pumps blood to pulmonary artery and aorta. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: The relaxation phase of the heart is called:
questions.explanation: Diastole is the relaxation phase of the heart chambers during which the chambers fill with blood. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: The stroke volume (SV) is defined as:
options: Volume of blood pumped by each ventricle per beat
questions.explanation: During a cardiac cycle, each ventricle pumps out approximately 70 mL of blood which is called the stroke volume. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: The stroke volume of a healthy person is approximately:
questions.explanation: During a cardiac cycle, each ventricle pumps out approximately 70 mL of blood which is called the stroke volume. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: Cardiac output is calculated as:
questions.explanation: Cardiac output = Stroke volume × Heart rate. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: The cardiac output of a healthy person is approximately:
questions.explanation: The cardiac output of a healthy individual is approximately 5 litres per minute (70 mL × 72 beats/min). (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: The first heart sound (lub) is produced when:
questions.explanation: The first heart sound (lub) is associated with the closure of the tricuspid and bicuspid valves. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: The second heart sound (dub) is produced when:
questions.explanation: The second heart sound (dub) is associated with the closure of the semilunar valves. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: Electrocardiograph (ECG) is a graphical representation of:
questions.explanation: An electrocardiograph (ECG) is the graphical representation of the electrical activity of the heart during a cardiac cycle. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: To obtain a standard ECG (Limb Lead), electrodes are placed on:
questions.explanation: To obtain a standard ECG or Limb Lead, electrodes are placed on both wrists and both ankles. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: The P-wave in ECG represents:
questions.explanation: The P-wave represents the electrical excitation (or depolarisation) of the atria, which leads to the contraction of both the atria. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: The QRS complex in ECG represents:
questions.explanation: The QRS complex represents the depolarisation of the ventricles, which initiates the ventricular contraction. (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: The T-wave in ECG represents:
questions.explanation: The T-wave represents the return of the ventricles from excited to normal state (repolarisation). (NCERT Page 234)

questions.question: In double circulation, blood passes through the heart:
questions.explanation: In double circulation, blood passes through the heart twice in each complete cycle - once through pulmonary circulation and once through systemic circulation. (NCERT Page 235)

questions.question: Pulmonary circulation involves blood flow between:
questions.explanation: Pulmonary circulation involves the flow of blood between the heart and lungs for oxygenation. (NCERT Page 235)

questions.question: Systemic circulation involves blood flow between:
questions.explanation: Systemic circulation involves the flow of blood between the heart and different parts of the body for supply of oxygen and nutrients. (NCERT Page 235)

questions.question: The hepatic portal system carries blood from:
questions.explanation: A unique vascular connection exists between the digestive tract and liver called hepatic portal system. The hepatic portal vein carries blood from intestine to the liver before it is delivered to the systemic circulation. (NCERT Page 235)

questions.question: The coronary circulation supplies blood to:
questions.explanation: A special coronary circulation is provided to supply blood to the heart muscles (myocardium) through coronary arteries and veins. (NCERT Page 235)

questions.question: Blood pressure is measured using:
questions.explanation: Blood pressure is measured using an instrument called sphygmomanometer. (NCERT Page 235)

questions.question: Normal systolic blood pressure in humans is:
questions.explanation: The systemic pressure is commonly measured in the brachial artery. Normal blood pressure is approximately 120/80 mm Hg. The systolic pressure is 120 mm Hg. (NCERT Page 235)

questions.question: Normal diastolic blood pressure in humans is:
questions.explanation: Normal blood pressure is approximately 120/80 mm Hg. The diastolic pressure is 80 mm Hg. (NCERT Page 235)

questions.question: High blood pressure (hypertension) is defined as blood pressure higher than:
questions.explanation: Blood pressure above 140/90 mm Hg is considered high blood pressure or hypertension. (NCERT Page 236)

questions.question: Atherosclerosis refers to:
options: Deposition of cholesterol and calcium in arteries
questions.explanation: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD), often referred to as atherosclerosis, affects the vessels that supply blood to the heart muscle. It is caused by deposits of calcium, fat, cholesterol and fibrous tissues, which makes the lumen of arteries narrower. (NCERT Page 236)

questions.question: Heart failure is also known as:
questions.explanation: Heart failure is sometimes called congestive heart failure because congestion of the lungs is one of the main symptoms of this disease. (NCERT Page 236)
